sen.j: 橋本駅 （はしもとえき）は、京都府八幡市にある、京阪電気鉄道京阪本線の鉄道駅。
sen.e: Hashimoto Station is a railroad station on the Keihan Electric Railway Main Line located in Yawata City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Hashimoto Station, located in Yawata City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a railroad facility on the Keihan Electric Railway Main Line.
Hashimoto Station, located in Yawata City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a railroad facility on the Keihan Main Line, which is operated by the Keihan Electric Railway.
sen.cmt: 一部表現を他ファイルと統一しました。

sen.j: 同線においては、大阪側から見て京都府内で最初の駅である。
sen.e: From the Osaka side, it is the first Keihan Main Line station located in Kyoto Prefecture.
From the Osaka side, it's the first Keihan Main Line station in Kyoto Prefecture.
From the Osaka side, it's the first Keihan Main Line station in Kyoto Prefecture.
Structure of the station
The station's structure
Station layout

sen.j: プラットホーム形状と配置2面2線を有する地上駅。
sen.e: The structure and layout of platforms: Hashimoto Station is a ground station with two platforms and two railway lines.
Hashimoto Station is a ground-level facility with two platforms and two railway lines.
It is an aboveground station with two separate platforms serving two tracks.
sen.cmt: 原文wikiを参照し、「相対式プラットフォーム」 としました。

sen.j: 改札口はホーム毎に分かれており、改札内で上下線ホーム同士の移動はできない（改札外に踏み切りがある）。
sen.e: Each platform has its own ticket gates, with no transfer allowed between the platforms for inbound and outbound trains (there is a crossing outside the ticket gates).
Each platform has its own ticket gates, but no transfer is allowed between the platforms for inbound and outbound trains (there is a crossing outside the ticket gates).
Each platform has its own ticket gates, and no transfer is allowed between the platforms for inbound and outbound trains (there is a crossing outside the ticket gates).

sen.j: なお、改札口は上下線ともホーム樟葉寄りにある。
sen.e: Ticket gates for both lines are on the side of the platforms toward Kuzuha Station.
The ticket gates for both lines are on the side of the platforms toward Kuzuha Station.
The ticket gates for both lines are on the side of the platforms toward Kuzuha Station.
Platforms
Platforms
Platforms
* Both of the platforms have an effective length for eight cars combined together.
* Each of the platforms has an effective length sufficient to accommodate eight cars.
* Each of the platforms has an effective length sufficient to accommodate eight cars.
No line numbers are displayed on the platforms.
No line numbers are displayed on the platforms.
No Platform numbers are displayed.

sen.j: 両ホーム共に両端には屋根がなく、梅雨時などは地元客からの不評を買っている。
sen.e: Neither platform has a roof on either of its ends, causing complaints among passengers during the rainy season.
Neither platform has a roof on either of its ends, and the lack of shelter causes complaints among passengers during the rainy season.
Neither platform has a roof on either of its ends, and the lack of shelter causes complaints among passengers during the rainy season.
Areas around the station
The area around the station
Station surroundings

sen.j: 古くは地名通り淀川にかかる橋（山崎橋）のたもとで、橋が失われてからは1962年（昭和37年）まで山崎との間に渡船があった。
sen.e: As its name (literally meaning "bridge end" in Japanese) suggests, Hashimoto Station is located at an end of a former bridge (Yamazaki-bashi Bridge) crossing the Yodo-gawa River; after the bridge was lost, there was a ferry service running between Hashimoto and Yamazaki, which continued to be operated until 1962.

As its name (literally "bridge end") suggests, Hashimoto Station is located at an end of a former bridge (Yamazaki-bashi Bridge) crossing the Yodo-gawa River; after the bridge was lost, there was a ferry service running between Hashimoto and Yamazaki, which operated until 1962.

As its name (literally "bridge end") suggests, Hashimoto Station is located at an end of a former bridge (Yamazaki-bashi Bridge) crossing the Yodo-gawa River; after the bridge was lost, there was a ferry service running between Hashimoto and Yamazaki, which operated until 1962.

sen.j: このため正式な宿ではないが京街道の宿場として賑わい、のちには遊郭街となった。
sen.e: For this reason, although Hashimoto was not officially a posting station during the Edo period, it flourished as a tourist town on the Kyokaido, subsequently becoming a red-light district.
So, although Hashimoto wasn't officially a posting station during the Edo period, it flourished as a tourist town on the Kyokaido, subsequently becoming a red-light district.
So, although Hashimoto wasn't officially a posting station during the Edo period, it flourished as a tourist town on the Kyokaido Road, subsequently becoming a red-light district.

sen.j: 駅西側には当時をしのばせる古い家並みが残る。
sen.e: There are rows of old Japanese houses on the west side of the station that are reminiscent of the old days.
The rows of old Japanese houses on the west side of the station are reminiscent of the old days.
The rows of old Japanese houses on the west side of the station are reminiscent of the old days.

sen.j: 現在駅東側は山を切り崩した住宅街になっているが、京阪電気鉄道の開発が入るまでは完全な山であり、石清水八幡宮の西側まで延々と獣道が続いていたが、麓の遊郭での諍いから遊女の自殺が絶えない地域でもあった。
sen.e: At present, the area on the east side of the station is a residential district that has been created by leveling off a mountain, but it was part of a natural mountain environment with animal trails running all the way to the west of Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, before it was developed by the Keihan Electric Railway; it was also known as an area where prostitutes often committed suicide as a result of quarrels in the red-light district at the foot of the mountain.

Currently, the area on the east side of the station is a residential district that has been created by leveling off a mountain, but it was part of a natural mountain environment with animal trails running all the way to the west of Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, before it was developed by the Keihan Electric Railway; it was also known for having area at the foot of the mountain where prostitutes would commit suicide as the result of quarrels in the red-light district at the foot of the mountain.

Currently, the area on the east side of the station is a residential district that has been created by leveling off a mountain, but it was part of a natural mountain environment with animal trails running all the way to the west of Iwashimizu-hachiman-gu Shrine, before it was developed by the Keihan Electric Railway; it was also known for having an area at the foot of the mountain where prostitutes would commit suicide as the result of quarrels in the red-light district.
sen.cmt: at the food of the mountain のダブりを削除しました。

sen.j: 駅から東へ登ると、氏神の狩尾神社がある。
sen.e: There is Toganoo-jinja Shrine a little above the east side of the station.
There is Toganoo-jinja Shrine slightly above the east side of the station.
There is Toganoo-jinja Shrine, which is a guardian deity of this area, slightly above the east side of the station.
sen.cmt: 氏神 の訳を追加しました。

sen.e: Saiyu-ji Temple and Kushuon-in Temple (used as the base camp of the Tokugawa shogunate army during the Battle of Toba-Fushimi in 1868)

sen.j: 駅のやや南の津田電線八幡工場跡地に京阪バス（旧京阪宇治交通）の京阪橋本バス停がある。
sen.e: At the site of the former TSUDA Electric Wire & Cable Company factory, which is located a little to the south of the station, there is Keihan Bus Company's Keihan Hashimoto bus stop.
At the site of the former TSUDA Electric Wire & Cable Company factory, which is located slightly south of the station, there is the Keihan Bus Company's Keihan Hashimoto bus stop.

History
History
History

sen.j: 1910年（明治43年）4月15日 - 京阪本線開通と同時に開業。
sen.e: Hashimoto Station opened on April 15, 1910 at the same time as the opening of the Keihan Main Line.
Hashimoto Station opened on April 15, 1910, concurrently with the opening of the Keihan Main Line.
April 15, 1910: Hashimoto Station opened and concurrently with the opening of the Keihan Main Line.

sen.j: 1943年（昭和18年）10月1日 - 会社合併により京阪神急行電鉄（阪急電鉄）の駅となる。
sen.e: On October 1, 1943, the station became a station of the Keihanshin Express Railway (or Hankyu Railway) as a result of a company merger.
On October 1, 1943, the station became a facility of the Keihanshin Express Railway (or the Hankyu Railway) as a result of a company merger.
October 1, 1943: The station became a facility of the Keihanshin Express Railway (or the Hankyu Railway) as a result of amalgamation.
sen.cmt: 会社合併→as a result of amalgamation として統一しました。日付表記変更

sen.j: 1949年（昭和24年）12月1日 - 会社分離により京阪電気鉄道の駅となる。
sen.e: On December 1, 1949, the station became a station of the Keihan Electric Railway as a result of a split-up of the railway company.
On December 1, 1949, the station became a station of the Keihan Electric Railway due to the split-up of the railway company.
December 1, 1949: The station became a station of the Keihan Electric Railway due to the split-up of the railway company.

sen.j: 1992年（平成4年）頃 駅舎改築・8連に対応する為にホーム延長・トイレ水洗化・スロープ改良される。
sen.e: Around 1992, the station building was renovated in order to expand the platforms for eight-car trains, install flush toilets and create slopes for wheel chairs.
In about 1992, the station building was renovated in order to expand the platforms for eight-car trains, install flush toilets and create slopes for wheelchairs.
About 1992: The station building was renovated in order to expand the platforms for eight-car trains, install flush toilets and create slopes for wheelchairs.
